comments.text:
Asbestos (pronounced /æsˈbɛstəs/ or /æzˈbɛstəs/) is a set of six naturally 
occurring silicate minerals which all have in common their eponymous 
asbestiform habit: long (roughly 1:20 aspect ratio), thin fibrous crystals.

Asbestos mining began more than 4,000 years ago, but did not start 
large-scale until the end of the 19th century when manufacturers and 
builders used asbestos because of its desirable physical properties: sound 
absorption, average tensile strength, its resistance to fire, heat, 
electrical and chemical damage, and affordability. It was used in such 
applications as electrical insulation for hotplate wiring and in building 
insulation. When asbestos is used for its resistance to fire or heat, the 
fibers are often mixed with cement or woven into fabric or mats.

The prolonged inhalation of asbestos fibers can cause serious illnesses 
including malignant lung cancer, mesothelioma, and asbestosis (a type of 
pneumoconiosis). The trade and use of asbestos have been restricted or 
banned in many jurisdictions.
comments.author: Pingy Penguinton

comments.text:
Only uranium 235 is used to make atom bombs and fuel nuclear reactors. The 
kind of uranium shipped with this toy would have been uranium 238, which is 
barely radioactive at all (a small chunk of it would irradiate you less 
than standing outside on a sunny day). Radiation has always been a big buzz 
word and people always seem to freak out when they hear things like this. 
Uranium is much more dangerous as a chemical toxin, as it is a heavy metal 
such as lead and causes much the same kind of damage to the body after 
repeated contact over time

comments.text:
That radioactive cloud chamber kit is superb. Cloud chambers are quite 
enthralling to watch, plus it teaches some proper science, instead of the 
usual fake microscope kids get.
Yeah, the radioactivity isn't much of a concern. However, just because 
U-238 (Depleted Uranium, known for its use as armour-defeating munitions) 
has very low emissions doesn't mean its just as safe the potassium in 
bananas. Potassium is relatively harmless, but Uranium is an extremely 
toxic heavy metal that accumulates in the liver and kidneys. It can stay in 
the body for an extremely long time (slowly ionizing the surrounding tissue 
with alpha emissions). When inhaled it can cause lung lesions, so small 
fragments are particularly concerning. It's also highly teratogenic, so 
keeping it away from children and pregnant women is generally a good idea. 
Radiation isn't really the main problem, think of it like handing a sample 
of cadmium or mercury to a child.

comments.text:
+puppydemon20  Actually you're wrong big time.
The company that ran the servers for the Wii's internet closed due to 
bankruptcy or something along those lines. The servers no longer exist and 
Nintendo didn't want to buy a new server service for the Wii as the system 
is over 6 years old and they have a new console to focus on.
To be honest the internet service for the Wii was slow, laggy, and 
disconnected unexpectedly way too often. The service they have for the WiiU 
is a hell of a lot better and more usable, but to call it good is debatable.

All in all it was a logical and business minded decision for them to make 
at a time where they ARE NOT FAILING but do have to tighten the belt to 
keep the business profitable.
And unlike Microsoft, Sony, or Sega (RIP), even if their company doesn't 
meet their ideal sales quotas they still have enough money set aside from 
the stuff that is working to try again.

Lol. Everything COULD be used as a weapon. Where there's a will there's a 
way. We don't even need arms and legs to kill someone if we got pissed off 
enough. But, not everything IS a weapon. Accidents happen to everyone 
eventually. This whole thing should be about what must be banned for having 
unexpected dangers. It's like the gun that operates the way it should 
versus the gun the will explode in your face because of an unknown 
manufacturer defect. One is obviously dangerous and will cause harm 
depending on how it's used. The other is unexpectedly dangerous and will 
cause harm even during perfectly safe use. Lawn darts have no unexpected 
dangers. Common sense dictates that you can hurt somebody with one and need 
to be careful with it.

top_comment.text:
It's not the toy, it's the children. Sure, sometimes the design is bad, but 
today's generation, kids should be way smarter and have more common sense.
Easy Bake=Don't put your fingers in it.
Clackers=Don't clack them like crazy and maybe something bad won't happen.
Aqua Dots=It's a kids toy, what kid would do that? And if you see a ominous 
man buying it, why would you buy it?
Uterus=It's a plush made for adults. Infants, don't take the damn thing off 
and choke yourself. Anything will choke you.
Skydancers=Don't put your face next to the fast spinning blades.
Lawn Darts=Alright, this killed a man. Don't have anything for this one. 
But this does look like it was built for adults 18-30.
Pokeballs=Don't stuff it up your nose, you twat.
Little boat=Blame the parents on this one. Rescue your fricking child.
Pool stick things=Shouldn't be on this list, not recalled.
Yo yo waterball=Yeah, I see a bunch of kids playing with this NEXT TO A 
DAMN FLAME. Also, those ropes are elastic and if it surrounds the neck it 
would probably break.
Hammocks=Babies, you know better to not twist around while resting.
CSI thing=I blame the company on this one. Though, I didn't hear any news 
reports stating "Child dies from Asbestos toy." Probably if the child ate 
it, then blame it on the child.
Penguin=It's designed so you don't open the damn thing. It's a toy, have 
fun with it.
Barbie=You thought too much about this one.
Energy lab=*chuckle* Yeah, fun fact. This is an old toy, do you think they 
had that much science back then? I know what you're thinking "Everyone 
knows uranium is toxic, dumbass." But again, it's an old product.﻿

comments.text:
+TheXtraMan
The OP's use of language left no ambiguity as to their meaning. This was 
clearly an acceptable use of the word 'damage'. Try replacing the word 
'damage' with 'injury' and it sounds wrong. Native speakers fully 
understand the sentence and are perfectly happy with it. The fact that you 
take issue with it only indicates that you are not as fluent in the 
language as the native speakers are (no surprise). To a native speaker, you 
look like a raving lunatic.

There is nothing 'more logical' about using 'damage' only for inanimate 
objects. The purpose of language is to communicate information. Using 
damage instead of injury does not impede communication. The intended 
meaning was communicated effectively and language was successful (Huzzah!). 
Also, Raluyen Skylance just wrecked you.

is the general statement to all while injury and harm are synonyms that can

comments.author: hughn dicarian

comments.text:
+hughn dicarian
Well most white English people are descended from Anglo-Saxons so heritage 
wise it is "them" who invented the language but I'm not talking about 
bloodlines and national heritage - I'm talking about it being your first 
language or at least one that you've mastered.

+TheXtraMan99  admitted that he hadn't mastered the English language yet 
he's belligerently trying to 'correct' people who've been speaking English 
their entire lives and his 'correction' isn't even accurate.

At some point in history, what he's saying would have been true but it 
isn't today - he doesn't know this because he hasn't learned 'actual 
English' meaning English that is used in 2015 by native speakers. My point 
about English professors was that they'd be the authority on what is and 
isn't acceptable formal English and 'damage' *can* be used when talking 
about human beings.

"Exposure to [whatever] can damage the skin"
"His body's taken a lot of damage over the years as a professional fighter"
"Do you want to protect yourself or deal some damage?" (Skyrim blacksmith)

It may have started out as incorrect usage but it's been acceptable speech 
for generations now so for him to say "hey you're speaking English wrong" 
to a native speaker is as foolish as it is patronising.
comments.author: RiC David

comments.text:
Was it palladium or polonium?

Because if it was the latter, by the old gods and the new, that's about as 
irresponsible as you can get, and I really doubt they would have been 
allowed to even do that. The "toy" would also have been exorbitantly 
expensive considering polonium is made by exposing bismuth to neutron 
bombardment... in a nuclear reactor... so I somewhat doubt a toy 
manufacturer would in any manner gain access to it.

If it was some palladium, though, that I would understand better. Pd-110 is 
a long half-life, beta-active isotope which has a natural abundance of 
about 12%, so it would make perfect sense to include that as a beta source 
in a kit like this. Palladium is a noble metal so it would just pass 
through the digestive system without reacting with the stomach acid 
(hydrochloric acid).

By the way, polonium's toxicity is mainly based on its radioactivity.

comments.author: alidan

comments.text:
There are reasons besides radioactivity why giving uranium to kids is a bad 
idea.

They probably used either natural or depleted uranium for this, and as far 
as radiation exposure goes, those are some of the safest radioactive 
materials in existence. The half-lives of both U-238 and U-235 are so long 
that you'd need a big lump of the stuff to get some meaningful Becquerels 
out of it.

On the other hand, since both isotopes are alpha-active, the main risk 
would be ingestion of the samples. The decay products also include things 
like radium and radon, but the amount of these would almost certainly be 
meaningless in a very small sample.

Even then, radiation would be the least of the problems, since uranium 
happens to be toxic (the term "heavy metal" should be familiar). Not as 
toxic as plutonium, of course, but I'm pretty sure it's more hazardous 
than, say, lead.

However: It would be exceedingly foolish to buy such a toy to a child young 
enough to eat the samples. It would be just fine to get that kind of set 
for someone in their teens who was interested in physics, as they (likely) 
wouldn't eat the samples. Their younger siblings could of course do that, 
but that would fall into the responsibility of the older siblings and 
parents to watch that doesn't happen, right?

And considering the amount of lead used in Chinese toy industry, I'd say 
having a small sample of uranium in a science kit was probably one of the 
less hazardous things that other contemporary toys included.

about children ingesting the radioactive material were raised. Keep in mind

like nuclear energy was the answer to all of our problems. Later on in the 
50's Ford would put out a concept for a nuclear powered car and, according 
to Dr. Michio Kaku, someone had designed a toaster that was powered by

comments.text:
What's the big deal? Uranium is an alpha emitter. The alpha particles won't 
even make it through your skin (they're large, so they can just pass 
through solid matter like the other kinds of nuclear radiation). The only 
way you could get irradiated by uranium would be eating it. But it has a 
relatively long half life (meaning it doesn't emit much particles), so 
you'd get heavy metal poisoning long before you've eaten enough to get 
radiation sickness. All in all, it's no more dangerous than lead.

top_comment.text:
Okay, just to clear things up about the Uranium, I want to share my 
knowledge, small yes, but very useful none the less.

1. You can go on Amazon and get Uranium. It's really no big deal. This is 
because It's under the legal limit of the amount you can sell at a time.

2. The mathematical chance of an ionizing particle of radiation actually 
hitting one your body's atoms, much less a very specific DNA molecule that 
might end up screwing up and giving you cancer, is EXTREMELY small. (watch 
Vsauce's video "You can't touch anything"

3. People act like just because it's Uranium it must be soooo extremely 
deadly because you could just pop that right into a reactor and bam! the 
whole thing goes into meltdown. Or you could put it into a bomb and now you 
have a nuclear weapon! .... No. Uranium has to be prepped ALOT before it's 
sent to reactors to be used. It needs to be about 2% refined into U235 for 
reactor use. and about 90%-100% for nuclear weapons.

Hopefully now you are less scared about being irradiated or disintegrated 
by nuclear bombs built from Uranium that your sketchy neighbor's child 
might get for Christmas. :)﻿

In response to #2: Yes, the mathematical chance of it happening is very 
small. However, your body has an EXTREMELY LARGE amount of DNA molecules, 
and uranium releases an extremely large number of ionizing particles. Even 
if the odds of me getting cancer from one particle is .0000001%, if I'm 
rolling the dice 1,000,000,000,000 times, my odds of getting cancer are 
pretty damn high.

Also, kids, and their younger siblings, have a tendency to swallow small 
objects. That can be a problem.

the smoke detectors were given to him, There was no theft, and smoke 
detectors do not have Uranium in them, they have Americium in them. He did 
build a small reactor with them though.

radiation it emits will never do anything to you unless you were to swallow 
it, even then it would be minimal since Uranium does not linger in your 
system for very long. I do believe that you can get a minuscule polonium 
source with those cloud chambers. Just look up information on alpha 
particle radiation.

I find it very silly that people freak out in such a hardcore way when any 
form of the words Nuclear, or Radiation are mentioned. It is this 
irrational fear that warranted the name change of the MRI. It used to be 
called the NMRI, the "N" standing for Nuclear. People were so afraid of the 
word that they wouldn't allow doctors to use the device on them.

If you fear something, RESEARCH IT. It is so stupid to live in the dark and 
fear something so benign as a small speck of Uranium ore...

choking hazard :) that wont end well. i suggest watching more periodic 
videos on uranium though, The Gold Finger, gamma radiation was from 
plutonium, not uranium, i would not blame the people who shut down the toy 
if it was plutonium, that stuff is just nasty. uranium as said, as long as 
not exposed to it for too long (i would not let someone around it any 
longer than a couple minutes), you should be ok (unless you extremely pale 
and are prone to radiation)

comments.text:
Gloves wouldn't do too much to protect you. They would stop the alpha 
radiation as they aren't very penetrating but the gamma radiation would 
penetrate the gloves very easily. If you did actually go and experiment 
with radioactive sources, hold them with tongs and as far away from the 
body as possible (due to the inverse square law: intensity of radiation is 
inversely proportional to the square of separation between the source and a 
body).

I had these red plastic water rockets when I was 10.  They were about 8 
inches tall.  They were made of clear, heavy plastic.  You filled them with 
water and then pumped air into them until your arms ached (or, until you 
broke the pump).  You then aimed them straight up in the air (not at a 
friend or stray animal; oh no, not ever) and WHOOSH!  They'd shoot about 
100 ft straight up, and then would come down.  If they landed on the lawn 
they'd be okay; if they landed on the pavement, they'd break.  Of course, 
if they landed on your buddy's little brother he'd scream like a 
fire-engine, bleed like a stuck pig, and you'd both get grounded.

top_comment.text:
Oh, and just to be clear, the Gilbert Atomic Energy Lab that I bought as a 
kid did NOT come with a chunk of Uranium as shown, it came with a little 
metal canister with holes in it.  I opened it, and inside was glued a 
sliver of a metal disk that had ground up Uranium peppered onto it.  You 
couldn't even see the Uranium it was so little!  BUT... still a little dry 
ice in the system to make a vapor, and turn off the lights and here and 
there a small spark could be seen popping through the cloud.  Later kits by 
other manufactures used Polonium 210, the material used in de-static 
brushes sold even today, they worked better.  And again to be clear, the 
Uranium in the Gilbert kit was U-238, and not fissile!  If they had given 
us smart kids a chunk of even U-238 as shown, the progress of nuclear power 
in America would today be far in advance of where it is.  Better yet, if 
they had given us even mildly fissile Thorium... everything we count on 
today for power generation would be evolved.  You see, kids... are the 
future!  As it is, its hard for kids to even get specialized pyrex lab 
ware.﻿

Corporations do things like this all the time. Tire companies are a perfect 
example. They know that with their current testing methods, that they will 
produce faulty tires from time to time, and get sued because of it. They 
already have the money set aside to settle lawsuits as a result of the 
accidents that their faulty tires caused. Why? Because they've already 
calculated that it would cost them less money to settle lawsuits than it 
would to have very strict quality control standards. Even if it's at the 
expense of their own customer's lives. Is it wrong? Of course. It speaks 
volumes about our society when profit margins are more valuable than human 
life.

comments.text:
The kids were probably 'not' trying to 'eat' the Pokeballs.  When I was a 
kid "L'eggs" panty hose came in fairly large plastic eggs.  You put them on 
your face and pretended you were a jet pilot, you know they used to show 
pilots on tv with masks on.  Of course, nobody told seven year olds that 
jet pilot masks have oxygen tubes that go into them.  Also, they make cool 
voice distorters.  So your kid isn't being a moron, he just isn't aware of 
the dangers.  As for the sky dancers, go to any toy store before you buy a 
present.  I used to watch little boys chase each other up and down the 
aisles 'shooting' sky dancers at each other like they were missiles. 
Clearly the makers of "Sky Dancers" missed their target audience.  As for 
Clackers...well, they were around in the United States in the early to mid 
seventies.  My aunts both had them.  Its a matter of skill, trying to make 
the two balls strike each other faster and faster until POW! they explode!
And the noise, the noise, the noise, noise, noise, noise!  Of course you 
got hit by them a lot, nobody would be impressed by the trick if you didn't 
occasionally get hurt.  "Wow, you learned to use a clacker.  I tried, but I 
kept getting hit in the face!"

comments.text:
Actually, in some parts of the world you can find rocks containing little 
amount of uranium. If you check them with Geiger counter, you get reading 
higher than background radiation. But this radiation is still in very small 
amount, and you are able to detect it only by placing your meter next to 
the rock. Stand half of a meter away and you won't be able to tell any 
difference.
Yeah, I know children toy with radioactive material sounds scary, but in 
fact it is no reason to freak out. It is possible, that you already had 
contact with some weak radioactive material if you are passionate about 
collecting minerals or own old grandfather's wristwatch with fluorescent 
pointers or simply live in certain area, where background radiation is 
higher due to geological reasons.

comments.text:
+musicalmario28 Yes, this is silly, and as far as I can tell, the kit was 
never actually recalled. It included several low-radiation sources, none of 
which were actually dangerous. The uranium in question was uranium ore, 
which is quite literally about as radioactive as a bunch of bananas.

And bananas *are* radioactive, believe it or not. They contain the 
radioactive isotope Potassium-40. Many people don't seem to realize that a 
lot of things we regularly encounter are radioactive to some degree.
comments.author: Cornelius Sneed

comments.text:
Are you fucking serious... depleted uranium is hardly dangerous at all. In 
fact, the military often uses large plates of it for armor shielding. The 
only type of Uranium that could pose some health hazard is enriched 
uranium, which is not available for commercial use.

comments.text:
+Ali Junaid You could just go to the website United Nuclear. They 
specialize in selling small amounts of uranium and other radioactive 
elements for educational and hobby researchers. They also have all manner 
of other science equipment and even DIY high powered lasers, for the 
aspiring mad scientist.

Edit: Correction, uranium containing ore is actually what it is, which is 
actually pretty safe. The vial of small bits they sell is safe enough to 
leave on a shelf without causing any appreciable change if I remember 
right. When in large quantities however the ore can begin to produce enough 
harmful radiation to be concerning, But I think it has to be dozens of 
pounds before you need to worry. Don't take my word for it though if you 
actually need that knowledge, ask a professional. I just have an interest 
in all manner of science.

comments.text:
You stop trying to shove me down.  I'm only trying to defend my point that 
consumers should look at packaging before deciding to buy.  It's common 
sense to look at something and think "Oh, this product could kill me if my 
children use it improperly, which they are bound to do.  I should stay away 
from it until they are older."  Rather than "Oh, this looks like a fun toy. 
 I'm going to buy it for my children and just hope they don't use it 
irresponsibly."  You see what I'm getting at now?  This statement applies 
to ALL toys marketed on this list.  I understand a lot of the other toys on 
this list being recalled.  Poison, disturbing content, etc, but you're 
grilling me for just calling out stupidity as the number one cause of these 
toys being recalled?  Well, maybe I'm wrong, but I never said I was right. 
 I only based my statement on WHAT I SAW IN THE VIDEO!  And a lot of claims 
he brought up, at least in my personal opinion, meant the consumer was just 
an idiot and did something with the toy that it was not meant for.

NOW STOP PUSHING ME, OR YOU WILL BE BLOCKED!!.

were recalled because of CONSUMER STUPIDITY?!"

comments.text:
+Sean Patterson I am not comparing bullfighters to Nazis. I was only using 
the example as something that would be controversial. Yes, bullfighting is 
part of Spain's tradition and history, but not the only one. Though legal 
(they can get away with it) it is still bloody and cruel. Some people may 
get a kick of watching an animal slowly dying being tortured, stabbed and 
taunted by a man, but I don't think most people do. When Barbie wears that 
costume, she endorses that practise, she's making it more popular. That is 
why it is controversial. If I had children I would definitely not give them 
this doll purely based on my ideas. I wouldn't like my children to think 
that it is ok to kill animals for fun. Other than that very few women have 
become bullfighters, it's a men thing. The other Spain's doll they released 
is dressed as a Flamenco singer, much better.

comments.author: ElectricHelloKitty

comments.text:
+alexcnb Although it's tragic that bulls are killed, you can't deny that it 
is an important part of Spanish history and culture.  It's not a good part, 
but it is still an icon of Spanish culture.  The Killing of the Bulls 
receives worldwide attention as a staple of Spanish cultural history.  How 
can you possibly compare that to the Nazis?  The Nazis were socialist 
dictators under Hitler's totalitarian regime.  I think that if you disagree 
with the outfit on the doll, don't buy it.  You shouldn't have to ruin it 
for the people who would actually want to buy it.  It's just a piece of 
plastic with clothes inspired by Spanish cultural history.  Yes It is cruel 
to the bulls, but the bulls aren't being slain by barbie dolls or kids. 
 Let the kids be kids.  Don't by it if you don't like it.  Simple as that. 
 Don't fuss.

comments.text:
+Shwah Gamer   Incredibly, you've just equated studying nuclear physics as 
a child, to getting pregnant as a fifth grader!?  Wow, now that's really 
ignorant.

     First of all, your issues with having to relate to others as an adult 
is based on immaturity, if your parents had prepared you as mine did me, 
that wouldn't even be a problem.

     Studying hard throughout youth gives people an ADVANTAGE, which is 
essential as you continue to get older.  I had lots of fun times, did all 
the things my friends did... just a lot less of those frivolities and a lot 
more studying and experimenting.  

     As an example, the work I accomplished in plasma physics by the time I 
was 10, was the basis of my university entrance process, and the start of a 
thread of work I accomplished till I was 14. That work got me a 'fully 
paid' college career at 17... that's over 7 years of ivy league, top notch 
education, with NO MONEY OWED!  

So for any of you reading this who are kids, or have kids... START EARLY!
comments.author: doceigen

comments.text:
+doceigen It's my firm belief that kids should enjoy their childhood while 
they have it. Not spent trying to grow up too fast like they do now. Just 
last year I met a pregnant fifth grader. Yes you read that right, a 
pregnant fifth grader. Seeing something like that makes me sick. I feel bad 
for that girl and her parents.

I mean I've seen a lot of pregnant girls in high school, understand that 
they probably did use protection and it just failed, but to see a freaking 
fifth grader pregnant that's just not right. I hate that I'm freaking 19 
years old, and I already have to start saying things like, "you know, when 
I was your age..." it makes me feel a lot older than I really am. It also 
makes me worried. I have a little sister, she's 1 1/2, and with the way I 
see kids today, I'm worried about what she'll grow into. If she started 
behaving like the kids I've seen I just don't know what I'd do.
comments.author: Shwah Gamers

comments.text:
+Carl Nantel I grew up playing video games, and watching cartoons during 
winter because I hated going out in the cold. I never cared much for 
sports, but I did like playing outside when the weather was hot. One of my 
favorite things to do as a kid was go swimming. I know how you feel. My 
cousins are both ten years old and they both have their own smartphones and 
iPads. They're spoiled to death and it makes me worried for their future. I 
didn't get my first phone until I was 17, and that was because it was when 
I started dating my boyfriend (now fiancee) so my parents wanted me to have 
it just in case. I believe you should get a phone when you're actually 
going to need it, not just so you can say you have one.
comments.author: Shwah Gamers

comments.text:
+Spartan - 500 a radiological bomb, yes, but then you can buy enough 
radioactive elements to make a bomb through x-ray machines and such. But to 
make a fission bomb, no. The kit doesn't come with centrifuges or gaseous 
diffusion piping, or chemical baths to separate plutonium, or pumps to 
supply enough water to a reactor to make plutonium without destroying it, 
and it doesn't contain enough to make a decent bomb (what's the point of 
making a nuclear bomb when it would probably be easier to get an equivalent 
10 tons of explosives or so), it doesn't have the complex detonation system 
needed to implode fissile material, point is, there is a LONG process, a 
very costly and conspicious process, between uranium 238 (and in small 
concentration 235) and an actual bomb. However, if you are talking about a 
radiological bomb, yeah, theyre pretty much just missing the conventional 
explosives.

comments.text:
I agree with you completely as well, there's a lot to be said about 
violence and guns, all of it coming more often than not from parents who 
didn't educate their children about them (even if you don't own a gun, you 
should still explain to your children how they work and how to respect 
them, chances are they'll come across one at some point in their life) but 
how a person acts, responsibly or not, isn't influenced by a gun (though 
I'm preaching to the quire on that one. Let me just put it this way. When 
there's a drunk driving accident, we blame the driver. When there's a 
bombing, we blame the bomber. But when there's a shooting, we blame the 
gun. (Preaching the the quire again I'm sure.) Anyway, I wish there were 
more movies about people acting responsibly with guns. Though that would be 
a pretty boring movie. People always see criminals affiliated with guns, 
but never the people who lawfully carry them, (usually because the 
preferred method is concealed, to avoid alarming anyone who may think 
they're a "bad guy" because of movies they've watched.) The best way to 
convince people that not all guns are with the bad guys (or even most, for 
that matter) is to show people that people who own guns are normal everyday 
people. (And no, that doesn't mean walking around starbucks, target, or 
wherever with a rifle slung on your back, that just scares people who can't 
tell the difference between everyday joe and a "bad guy.") That would 
probably take people having friends over and showing them that you have a 
gun, and obviously they know you aren't a "bad guy" if they're your friends 
and just telling them why you have it and whats up with gun control if they 
seem interested in getting one themselves. Maybe even take them to the 
range if they get interested with the idea of owning a gun. Anyway, don't 
think you were expecting the response you got from me, huh? :D XD Have a 
nice day sir!

captions.text:
• From sky-dancing Barbies that can cut
your face open, to sticks that can gouge out

your eyeballs, we count 15 dangerous and ridiculous
toy ideas to get recalled en masse

15 - Easy Bake Oven
• These were originally made for kids in

the 1960s when companies noticed they liked
to mimic things adults do, so they'd manufacture

toy cars or, in this case, a cooking appliance
• And apparently kids also liked getting

their fingers burnt off, which we can see
here with the Easy Bake Oven

• In 2007, Hasbro recalled almost a million
ovens after 200 reports of kids jamming their

appendages in the oven's opening, and a 5
year old girl whose finger got partially amputated

from severe burns
• I'd like to believe her finger got stuck,

and she didn't willingly sit for hours wondering
why her skin seemed to be melting off

14 - Clackers
• These came out in the 70s, and they're

still around today - two rock-hard balls held
together by cords with a design inspired by

nothing sexual
• The problem with Clackers is that they're

adept at caving in your face, breaking off
teeth and causing violence on par with acts

of terrorism
• In fact, the design was so shoddy that

most of the time the ball would break off
the string and go flying off to break some

expensive china or kill a small infant
• They weren't technically recalled, just

redesigned to be safer, so you might still
encounter these in dark alleyways

13 - Aqua Dots
• You know these - the small jewellery beads

you glue together under water to form patterns
• What you didn't know is that they could

also be used to drug and rape women at nightclubs
• In 2007, it was discovered that the glue

contained chemicals that metabolised into
GHB, the date-rape drug

• The toy's manufactorer blamed a Chinese
subcontractor and recalled all 4.2 million

Aqua Dot kits, then rebranded them Pixos still
available today

• So if you're ever in a dark nightclub
and you manage to avoid the Clackers, be wary

what jewellery might end up in your drink
12 - Plush Toy Uterus

• A common gift for any child, this adorable
female genitalia toy was manufactored by I

Heart Guts - and while you might think it
was recalled because someone came along and

said it was inappropriate, no, the truth is
those ovaries could be detached and transformed

into a choking hazard for infants
• Yes, that which gave the child life could

also take it away with a big smile on its
face

• Thankfully they voluntary recalled it
and released a new version that probably can't
kill you

11 - Barbie Sky Dancers
• A lot of people should remember this one,

I know I certainly do since my sister was
always catapulting them through the air where

they'd spin all the way to the ground
• And now I've just learned these twirling

death machines caused innumerable blindness,
broken teeth, facial lacerations, concussions

and even comas in kids - so now I feel quite
lucky to be alive

• Almost 9 million were recalled in the
year 2000, and the bloodshed concluded

10 - Lawn Darts
• Nothing spells death like throwing a weighted,

sharp, metallic flying object at your sibling
only for it to impale them because, whoops,

someone gave you a lawn dart
• These came out in the 70s, when dangerous

toys seemed to roam freely, and it took 18
years and three deaths for Health & Safety

officials to realise that maybe giving infants
a metal tipped projectile wasn't the smartest

thing to do
• Ideally you throw the dart at a ring on

the ground, but this was clearly not so, thus:
not only were these darts recalled - they

were banned forever
9 - Burger King Pokeballs

• This one is just ridiculous and just shows
how far kids are willing to go to suffocate

themselves
• The pokemon craze, mid to late 90s, Burger

King hands out pokeball toys with little figures
inside, not really a problem and we all remember

this promotion
• But somehow, heaps of kids were getting

half the ball stuck between their nose and
mouth, choking themselves to death with 3

inches of plastic
• I don't even... I can't... I don't understand

8 - Inflatable Baby Boats
• This one happened not too long ago - 2009,

a scumbag move by company Aqua-Leisure who
designed these floaty boats for infants

• There was a problem with the leg straps,
they would tear and the child would sink straight

through it and drown
• Over four million boats were recalled

after Safety officials found out Aqua-Leisure
had KNOWN about the issue for 6 years and

done nothing - they were fined $625,000
• Personally, I would've made their employees

sail across the Pacific Ocean on a boat filled
with holes, but I guess a fine works too

7 - Dive Sticks
• These are thrown into a pool with certain

number scores printed on them - the objective
is to dive under the water and collect as

many as you can before they sink to the bottom
• The obvious conclusion you might come

to is, well, kids are drowning looking for
all the damn sticks - but you're wrong

• The reason these were recalled? Impalement,
oh yes, eye gouging - these sticks butcher

up kids aged between 6 and 9
• You can still get them today, but they've

been redesigned to not carve up your face
meat

6 - Yo-Yo Water Balls
• Or more commonly known as explosive suffocation

bombs - some of these balls were made of a
flammable diesel hydrocarbon, which means

if you take it near an open flame, the ball
will ignite and the fire will climb the yo-yo

rope to burn your finger off - not an ideal
way to spend a Sunday afternoon

• Likewise, the long stretchy cord has been
known to strangulate people from time to time

- and there's even a health & safety law prohibiting
yo-yo water ball cords over 500mm in length

in Australia
• That's IF you've survived a Clacker assault

in a nightclub with one hand cupped over your
beer glass

5 - Mini-Hammock
• More strangulation for the little guys,

a problem for children in the years 1984 through
1995

• These tiny hammocks didn't come with a
spreader bar like you'd expect in a full-sized

version, which meant they'd get twisted in
the net until they lose all oxygen

• It got so bad that one child even suffered
permanent brain damage from oxygen loss, prompting

3 million hammocks to get recalled
• The ones that didn't go back are now thrown

over bombs to choke the blast
4 - CSI: Fingerprint Examination

• A way to let your infant children participate
in a gruesome murder show without even seeing

a dead body
• The powder used to examine fingerprints

contained asbestos - and the toy makers didn't
even care, when told to take it off the shelves,

they refused because the Christmas rush was
about to start

• The Asbestos Disease Awareness Organisation
replied, nup, nup, you think you can do this,

but, you're wrong - and they filed a civil
action lawsuit to stop sales of the kit

3 - Toy Penguin Figures
• On the surface, this one looks alright

- just a cutesy penguin that jingles when
you shake it

• Then one kid wanted to see how it worked,
so he pulled the penguins head off and exposed

a series of sharp, deadly nails holding everything
together

• So the kid was all like, nup, you THINK
you can lacerate me, but nup

• The company recalled thousands of these
penguins in 2008

2 - Spanish Barbie
• Everyone knows Barbie, a massive age-old

collectors series of dress-up models
• Then one day, along comes Spanish Barbie

wearing the typical matador's costume wielding
a red sheet on her arm

• So then everyone turned around to say,
hey come on, you can't portray the costume

worn when bulls are slaughtered en masse for
the amusement of a crowd on a Barbie - or

any other doll
• Thousands wrote to Mattell asking them

to discontinue the toy, including actress
Alicia Silverstone

1 - Gilbert U-238 Atomic Energy Lab
• Well, geez, why was this one recalled?

It couldn't be because the kit included actual
Uranium, and order forms so you could actually

get MORE Uranium delivered to your house - could
it?

• This children's lab set came with real
radioactive material, and you could witness

mist trails created by particles of ionizing
radiation - and nobody took a step back to

say, well, actually, now that I think about
it, maybe we SHOULDN'T irradiate our children
